title: Cat. 121  Bottle, 1st/2nd century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Bottle  
1st/2nd century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, blown; h. 21.7 cm (8 1/2 in.); diam. 13.3 cm (5 1/4 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.458

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Colorless glass with a bluish-green tinge. Blown and tooled. The rim, rounded by reheating, flares out from a long cylindrical neck. The vessel wall spreads out to form a convex shoulder and bends inward to a short, tapering body. The underside has a high kick with a pontil mark. For a zoomable image, see fig. 121.1.

The bottle is broken and repaired with some small losses, pitted surface. It has an overall brilliant iridescence.

This bottle is a very simple form but retains brilliant iridescence. There are two other ordinary vessels that have been selected for publication owing to their spectacular coloration: see cat. 119 and cat. 120.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 121 Bottle, 1st/2nd century A.D.

fig. 121.1 Bottle (1st/2nd century A.D.). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1949.458. Zoomable image.

</section>
